properties.media:imagetext:
SHANGHAI
FEB. 23, 1933
Dearest Debs.
You have the weather to thank, or blame, for this letter. I
started to go
out to see the movie Grand Hotel which I hav e always missed at St.
Louis,
New York
Bolton and other American metropolitan centers,
but when I got ready to call one of
the many Richsha boys the rain was coming down in torrents,
so decided to stay
in
my room,
My night boy was much relieved when I came back - he tried to tell me that
the rain was coming down in bucket fulls be fore I went out - but all I
could
make
out of his conversation was "Master no go, velly bad lain, catchy cold". Didn't make
up my mind as to what he had said until later - his talk was not as plain as it looks
in print. He is always most solicitous about me and gives me
such service as you
have never known.
The Hotel requests that tips be within reason and
suggests about
five cents,
good
educating to get
are about fifty - and I guess they are afraid some of the
"boys"
will retire if the guests get liberal. Everyother word
with them is "Catchy".
"Shall Master
catchy bath, or catchy bleakfast, catchy laundry, etc." They never get
an "r". You get so used to saying "nore big"
and "more high"
and such
"Pigeon" talk
that its very hard to keep those expressions out of your ordinary conversation with
other people not Chinese.
It is quite easy to get around whereever you want to
go without knowing
any Chinese.
Almost all of them here in Shanghai
speak some English,
at least enough
to direct you.
Have given up all idea, if I
ever had any, of trying to learn their
language. The written characters are the same all over China,
but the spoken words
are entirely different in sound. For instance the numeral
in Canton, and "Sen"
in Shanghai. Two is "Liang"
So a man from Canton might as well be in Germany as here, so far as making himself
understood is concerned, unless he knows how to write. This is one reason for their
lack of unity, but a more important factor is the fact that a mans family come first
followed by his city, then by his province and last the nation. One of the men I
have met here told me of having dined with a Chinese woman the night before. She had
been educated abroad and spoke English perfectly. During the course of the dinner
he asked her where she was from in China and she told him the name of a small town
in one of the Southern provinces. He remarked that she did not use the dialect of
that district, and she exclaimed
"Oh my family left there two hundred
years ago. He
admitted that was an extreme case because she was very proud of her ancestry, but
said that he had run across innumerable cases where the man or woman had never seen
their"home"
as they called it.
The Chinese who leave for other countries seem to
develop a rather keen love for the "Fatherland"
but that is not true of
those who
stay home. This fact has misled a lot of
people in the United States and elsewhere
to expect a lot more National cooperation in the Jehol area than will probably be
forthcoming.
I do hope there may be some way out of that threatened calamity. Wrote
to Walter Weisenburger yesterday and told him that he probably knew more about what
was going on over here through the St. Louis Press than I do - unless he says "Star"
instead of "Paper",
The
field for Aviation is apparently
almost unlimited because of the lack
of transportation facilities between large centers of
population. Most travel is by
water,
the service is infrequent, extremely slow and schedules poorly maintained.
There
is a tremendous interest in Airtransport but they seem to know very little
about flying boats, which it seems to me are much more practicable for operation
over here than land equipment. All the large cities are on or near water, airports
are hard to secure, and the whole life and habit of the people is, and has been for
centuries, controlled by availability of vator transportation. The nest sie ba bad.
ing Equigment with gold and paying for it in depreciated
Had
